title: Problem Documentation
content: This header documents **Erdős Problem #351**, asking whether the set {p(n) + 1/n} is strongly complete for polynomials p(x). The general problem is OPEN, but specific cases have been solved.
mathContext: Strong completeness means: for any finite 'forbidden' set B, the finite sums from A \ B contain all sufficiently large integers. This is stronger than ordinary completeness.

title: Imports and Namespace
content: We import Mathlib and open **Polynomial**, **Finset**, **Filter**, and **Set** namespaces for working with polynomials, finite sets, filters, and set operations.

title: Image Set Definition
content: The **image set** for polynomial P is {P(n) + 1/n : n ∈ ℕ}. For p(x) = x, this gives {1+1, 2+1/2, 3+1/3, ...} = {2, 2.5, 3.33..., ...}.
mathContext: We define `imageSet P` as the range of the function n ↦ P.eval(n) + 1/n over natural numbers. Note that n=0 contributes P(0) since 1/0 = 0 in this context.

title: Strong Completeness
content: A set A is **strongly complete** if for ANY finite set B we remove, all sufficiently large integers can still be written as finite sums from A \ B.
mathContext: Formally: ∀ B : Finset, ∀ᶠ m in atTop, ∃ X ⊆ A \ B with X.sum = m. The 'eventually' (∀ᶠ) means 'for all sufficiently large m'. This uses Mathlib's filter-based eventually predicate.

title: Strongly Complete Image
content: **HasStronglyCompleteImage(P)** means the image set {P(n) + 1/n} is strongly complete. This is the property Erdős asked about.

title: General Problem (Open)
content: **Erdős Problem #351** asks: for every polynomial p(x) with positive leading coefficient, is {p(n) + 1/n} strongly complete? This general question remains **OPEN**.
mathContext: We represent the open status with a trivial axiom. The answer is unknown—it could be true or false. Specific cases have been resolved, but the general pattern is not understood.

title: Graham's Theorem (p = x)
content: **Graham (1963)** proved that {n + 1/n : n ∈ ℕ} is strongly complete. Even after removing any finite set of terms, all large integers are representable.
mathContext: This is stated as `HasStronglyCompleteImage X` where X is the polynomial x. Graham's proof uses intricate partition arguments and is a landmark result in additive number theory.

title: Graham-Alekseyev Theorem (p = x²)
content: The set {n² + 1/n : n ∈ ℕ} is strongly complete. Van Doorn noted this follows from combining Graham's 1963 result with Alekseyev's 2019 work on partitions into squares.
mathContext: Stated as `HasStronglyCompleteImage (X ^ 2)`. Alekseyev studied partitions into distinct squares whose reciprocals sum to 1, which connects to this problem.

title: Image Set Membership
content: We verify that n + 1/n ∈ imageSet(X) and n² + 1/n ∈ imageSet(X²) for all n. These follow directly from the definition by exhibiting n as a witness.
mathContext: The proofs use `Set.mem_range` and simplification of polynomial evaluation. For X, eval(n) = n; for X², eval(n) = n².

title: Bounds on n + 1/n
content: We prove: (1) n + 1/n > n for n ≥ 1, and (2) n + 1/n < n + 1 for n ≥ 2. The special case n=1 gives exactly 2.
mathContext: The lower bound uses positivity of 1/n. The upper bound uses 1/n < 1 when n ≥ 2. For n=1, we have 1 + 1/1 = 2 = 1 + 1, so it's not strictly less.

title: Concrete Examples
content: We verify: **1 + 1/1 = 2**, **2 + 1/2 = 5/2**, **3 + 1/3 = 10/3**. These use `norm_num` for automatic verification.
mathContext: These concrete values show the sequence: 2, 2.5, 3.333..., 4.25, 5.2, ... The terms are 'almost integers' that grow roughly linearly.
